The the most personally interesting aspect to this is that, you know, as a young child, I felt kind of very apart and very different. And that's a feeling that was lost through socialization over time. And that tends to be the case. It's sort of reminding me of that now. That tends to be the case. It tends to be that those who are on a genuine path to truth with, you know, with varying degrees of sincerity tend to be individuals who did not fit into, the the norms of society. They tend to be, fringe individuals, fringe in the sense of, you know, not socialization tends not to be their their, the the thing that that moves them the most. Thank you for your time and your work. Namaste.

blocks.text: Before I started to read your work, I was going through one of the worst phase in my life. You know, I was jumping from this book to that book, this book to that book every time. And after I started to read a book, it's the like, I get every time I read a work, every time I listen to a, like, interview, I get extremely strong emotional reaction. Sometimes, you know, I get so emotional. It lasts for, like, week and some you know, the thing that I read about your work or, like, even writings, anything that I hear from you, It lasts for, like, months sometimes. It has been hap happening for a long time now. It has been almost a year. Is it, can I say that I am part towards truth, or is it still that I am thinking through my mind? I mean, I don't I don't know. I can't tell you to which degree you're thinking through your mind or not. I mean, generally speaking, everyone is lost in mind. But the truth the truth tends to have a fairly significant effect upon some people. So it's not me. It's just the power of the truth.

blocks.title: Q44
blocks.text: Hey, Kapil. Thanks for having me, and, thank you for everything that you do. I read your discourse about anger and the truth, of anger, which really helped me, conquer my anger. I used to struggle with that a lot. One of the things which I've been struggling all my life and has plagued me is fear and anxiety, and I've been desperately looking for answers. I've read your discourse, and you mentioned that fear is the ultimate fear is fear of oneself, how how one might think about oneself. I read Osho, and Osho says it's ultimately we fear death. And I've been reading Krishnamurti and Jed McKenna, but I still haven't been able to truly understand, like, are are all these is there any ultimate fear which all the grades are talking about, including you? No. Because everyone talks about everything from a standpoint of prescription. Right? And wherever wherever there's a prescription, do this or do that or pretend this or think that or try this or meditate this or mindfulness that. That's just the way to keep you exactly where you are. So that that that's the most critical thing for anybody. It isn't to move away from prescription. It is to it is to understand if they are willing and interested to look into the nature of prescriptions and how they abandon, and stand in the way of of human progress.
